snippet: A study of college students found that the trend toward more class participation, and away from a traditional lecture-based approach, raised average test scores, with bigger gains for some.
abstract: Study of college students published in journal CBE Life Sciences Education reveals that class participation has most profound effects on black students and students whose parents did not go to college; finds that active learning raised average test scores more than 3 percentage points, and significantly reduced the number of students who failed exams.
lead_paragraph: A study of college students found that the trend toward more class participation, and away from a traditional lecture-based approach, raised average test scores, with bigger gains for some.

headline.main: Active Role in Class Helps Black and First-Generation College Students, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Active Role in Class Helps Black and First-Generation College Students, Study Says
